awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Phase I Rutgers, Newark: Center for Accelerated Real Time Analytics (CARTA)
awd_abstract_narration:
Nearly every research field and industry sector is struggling with extracting useful information from massive and dynamic data in a timely way. Developing tools and technologies in this realm of real-time and accelerated analytics contributes to promoting the progress of science and to advancing the national prosperity and welfare. Success in this realm hinges on balancing fundamental research, technological know-how, and commercial market intelligence. To address this challenge, this project joins industry members with academic centers to conduct multidisciplinary science and research towards extracting value from massive and moving data  and enabling better decision making of complex, dynamic data.

The Center of Accelerated Real Time Analytics (CARTA) project explores the ways in which relatively-high-risk fundamental developments can be leveraged to help organizations that have longer-term, more complex analytic needs. The focus of CARTA is on horizontal foundational technologies that would create an infrastructure capable of powering applications of national significance. Research at the Rutgers-Newark CARTA site will enable the development of real time data analytics approaches addressing challenges in personalized medicine, safety monitoring and adverse event prediction, and genomics analysis.  An overarching goal is to develop holistic, real-time views of heterogeneous data integrated into the social and mobile world.

The broader impact of the work of the CARTA center will be in addressing the future advanced, real-time analytics needs of the industry and society. The techniques developed by CARTA can be applied across industry sectors, including national security, healthcare, manufacturing, energy, and business intelligence. The fundamental research done at CARTA will be translated into technology developments, delivering practical solutions to hard problems. The ultimate success of this paradigm shift by the analytics industry will rest on the ability of CARTA universities to prepare experts to take advantage of the science and technologies to solve a variety of real-life applications.

CARTA research may involve sensitive academic and industrial data along with public domain data.  This data and resulting research outputs will be maintained using appropriate best practices for each type of data for a period of three years after the closing of CARTA.  A central repository, suitably tagged for appropriate referencing and documentation, will be set up at https://carta.umbc.edu for maintaining the acquired and generated data from Center projects. Project results will be made available in response to approved user requests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to establish a research site at Rutgers University - Newark for a new NSF Phase I I/UCRC on accelerated real time analytics (CARTA) led by the University of Maryland Baltimore County. The mission of CARTA is to advance research and education focusing on real time analytics of large datasets on superfast highly scalable next generation hardware like graphics hardware acceleration, and new technical approaches like Deep Learning, Cognitive computing - Smart "self learning" systems and accelerated graph analytics. The strategic research areas will be towards accelerated Computing, Cybersecurity, Internet of Things (IoT) and real time Healthcare analytics. The Rutgers CARTA site will develop novel algorithmic solutions for problems in various domains such as community resilience, e-government and e-commerce, and healthcare informatics.

 

Intellectual merit outcomes

  • We have developed an integrated ontology-based reasoning framework for dynamic composition and management of emergency response processes. We validated its effectiveness by implementing FEMA Hazardous Materials Tabletop Exercise scenario and COVID-19 response scenario.
  • We have developed a framework for debugging and automated repair of business process (BP) workflow applications. This framework called, Collaborative Fault Resolution (CFR), utilizes the knowledge of existing BPs to locate and group the minimum set of differences that can be used to repair a faulty BP. Our experimental evaluation shows that CFR is highly efficient and provides reasonable accuracy when there is considerable overlap between a faulty BP and existing BPs.
  • We developed news categorization machine learning models that can group news articles into meaningful categories, identify redundant articles, and summarize them into succinct abstracts.  A Web application for News classification has been developed and delivered to the industry partner, which is being incorporated into their existing software platform.
  • We proposed an efficient incremental ABAC policy maintenance approach that does not require re-mining of ABAC policies whenever there is a change.
  • We have analyzed the incidence of comorbidity between CIDP and other autoimmune disorders and investigated the relationship between the occurrence of comorbid conditions/ adverse side effects and the treatment used to manage CIDP. We have investigated trends in management of IVIG and compared trends in outcomes and global charges of CIDP patients treated with IVIG compared to corticosteroids. We have also investigated whether or not there is an association between CIDP and Diabetes by investigating the comorbidity profile of patients before and after the diagnosis of CIDP.
  • We have developed an approach to assess and analyze the privacy disclosure risk in the social media posts by a user when sharing information online.

Broader impact outcomes

  • 8 PhD dissertations resulted from the research conducted during this project.
  • 6 Masters students' and 1 postdoctoral fellow's projects are based on the work performed during this project.
  • Several refereed conference and journal publications resulted from the research and development work performed during this project.
  • Several spin-off funding resulted from the research and development work performed during this project.

 


Last Modified: 03/14/2022
Modified by: Vijayalakshmi Atluri
